document.masterDocTitle: More species of the Agononida incerta complex revealed by molecules and morphology (Crustacea: Decapoda: Anomura: Munididae)

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 7 .
Agononida norfocerta
. Female, 27 mm, paratype, Norfolk Ridge, NMV J62814: a, anterolateral margin of telson; b, pereopod 1, upper and lateral views. Anterolateral margins of telson: c, male, 26 mm, Fiji, MNHN IU-2010-6145; d, supermale, 35 mm, Fiji, MNHN IU-2010-6115; e, ovigerous female, 29 mm, Fiji, MNHN IU-2010-6114. Drawings to same scale.

. Bligh Water:

16 ° 53 'S
,
177 ° 44 'E

2 males
, 13 mm ; female 13 mm ).

Colour . Generally orange; red band at end of merus of cheliped, deeper orange bands and ends of carpus and across propodus-fingers articulation; red dots at ends of meri and carpi of pereopods 2–4 ; deeper orange patch on extensor margin of propodus of pereopod 2 , larger on pereopods 3 and 4 and extending on to dactyli (except for white tip). Based on MNHN IU- 2011 - 891 from Fiji .
Distribution . PNG , Qld ( Australia ), New Caledonia , Vanuatu , Fiji , 02°S to 23 °S, 300–1000 m (median 570 m ) depth.

Remarks .
Agononida norfocerta
is recovered within clade B, basal to the group comprising
A. auscerta , A. incerta
and
A. rubrizonata
(
Fig. 1
). The species is recognised by the tuberculate, slightly upturned, thin, almost liplike appearance of the medial part of the anterolateral margin of the telson with an obvious hiatus (at about 70 % of the margin length) between it and the more depressed, tuberculate and thicker posterior lobe (
Fig. 7
). The upturned section is more obvious in adult males than in females and juveniles. This is illustrated for a female from the type series and a male, supermale and female from Fiji .

The distribution of
A. norfocerta
, originally known only from the Norfolk Ridge, is extended north-westwards to PNG , west to the Queensland coast of Australia , and east to Fiji . Identifications from these new localities were confirmed by positions of some individuals in the molecular tree. Pereopodal dactyli in material from Fiji appear narrower ( 7 times as long as wide vs 6 times) than in the type material. The numbers of robust setae on the dactyli of pereopods 2–4 vary considerably between individuals and even between the right and left sides of a single individual. Regional median values of counts for the 30 additional specimens from Vanuatu , Fiji and Queensland are virtually the same as those from the type locality, 14, 3 and 1 respectively. Some individuals from PNG are exceptional in having more than 20 robust setae on the pereopod 2 dactylus; others have as few as seven. The ranges and median values in the diagnosis above have been adjusted.
